# Law Firms Should Skip Attorney Reviews This Year
## In this extraordinary -- yes, let's go with that adjective -- year, such reviews may do more damage than good.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onNovember 11, 2020 at 3:02 PMNovember 11, 2020 at 1:13 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/law-firms-should-skip-attorney-reviews-this-year/&text=Law%20Firms%20Should%20Skip%20Attorney%20Reviews%20This%20Year)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/law-firms-should-skip-attorney-reviews-this-year/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/law-firms-should-skip-attorney-reviews-this-year/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
One of the perks about having my own practice is that I do not need to complete many of the purely administrative tasks that attorneys at numerous law firms need to perform. For instance, I do not typically need to log my business development or pro bono hours, I just complete the work, and it doesn’t normally matter if those hours are counted. In addition, [my two-attorney law firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com) run by my brother and me does not have an attorney review process (although it would be interesting for the two of us to talk about our performance, maybe like an “[airing of the grievances](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1l8Eag9CAFk)”!). Since it is almost the end of the year, many firms across the country are about to begin or are currently undergoing their annual attorney review process. I have already discussed in a prior article how [attorney reviews are often a waste of time](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/03/associate-job-reviews-are-usually-a-big-waste-of-time/), and in this extraordinary year, such reviews may do more damage than good. For a variety of reasons, law firms should skip attorney reviews this year.

As many attorneys know from first-hand experience, attorney reviews can often be time consuming. Attorneys usually need to complete a questionnaire on their performance to kick off the review process, and this is often reviewed by managers, who must also write their own comments. People are extremely busy and distracted this year, for obvious reasons. Attorneys need to be flexible when managing childcare, overseeing schooling, and completing other tasks as many people work from home. Attorneys do not need to have one more, entirely administrative task to complete, and firms can give attorneys a huge morale boost if they are empathetic to their employees during this trying time.

Attorney reviews can also be extremely stressful on many lawyers. Lawyers often feel that they are being scrutinized during reviews, and if they do not justify how they deserve to stay at a firm, they may end up on the chopping block. This can lead them to spend an inordinate amount of time on completing self-evaluations and other steps related to the review process. Normally, attorneys do not need to feel too much stress related to the review process, since their jobs are typically secure unless they truly fall below expectations.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
However, the economy is extremely unstable, and the unemployment rate is at its highest in recent memory due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Firms have cut salaries and conducted layoffs throughout the year in order to deal with economic conditions. Even if attorney jobs are secure (and some firms have publicly acknowledged as much), there is still a justifiable fear that the attorney review process may decide a lawyer’s fate at a firm, even if this is not the case. Firms can eliminate this fear altogether if they simply skip the attorney review process.

Moreover, it is unfair in many attorney reviews to hold associates responsible to the same expectations that would be normal for other times. For instance, many law firms have an established billable hour requirement, mandating that attorneys log a set number of hours over the course of a calendar year. However, numerous attorneys had difficulty meeting billable hour requirements this year due to issues caused by the pandemic. As I can somewhat attest to [from personal experience](https://abovethelaw.com/small-firm-center/2020/05/should-covid-19-status-be-a-protected-classification/), falling ill from COVID-19 can make it difficult to bill hours and fulfill other work responsibilities, especially if you have more serious health impacts from the virus. In addition, many attorneys were impacted by the loss of loved ones, and this could make it difficult to satisfy firm expectations. Moreover, the challenges of working from home, as well as juggling schooling and other responsibilities, can make it difficult to meet billable hours and other expectations. Firms should have compassion for their attorneys in this environment. Sparing them from justifying shortfalls in an attorney review may be the right thing to do.

Of course, firms often make decisions about raises and bonuses through the attorney review process, and firms may have a more difficult time evaluating associates without a review. However, firms can always adopt a lockstep model when determining raises and bonus, so that everyone that has satisfactorily performed during a year can earn a raise or a bonus. Indeed, many firms adopt a lockstep model for determining raises and bonuses under normal circumstances. [As discussed in a prior article](https://abovethelaw.com/small-firm-center/2019/02/associates-should-share-salary-information-with-each-other/), paying attorneys uniformly on an objective basis also helps eliminate the possibility that attorneys are paid different salaries based on subjective or even objectionable grounds. Firms can always return to holistic determinations about salaries and bonuses when the pandemic subsides if they so choose.

All told, attorneys (and just about everyone else) have faced unprecedented challenges this year, and many people are feeling stressed as the year comes to a close. As a result, law firms should consider skipping their traditional attorney review process to eliminate a source of stress and be more equitable in this difficult time.

text:
[  ](/)	[Home](/) | [Archive](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/archive/) | [RSS](/feed/) | [Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/howappealing) | [Contact](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

	

Wednesday, May 17, 2017
“Second Amendment case Peruta vs. California may be heading to Supreme Court”: Steve Kurtz and Georeen Tanner of FoxNews.com have [this report](http://www.foxnews.com/us/2017/05/15/second-amendment-case-peruta-vs-california-may-be-heading-to-supreme-court.html).

Posted at [10:30 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71625) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Supreme Court May Weigh Big Weapon for U.S. Companies Sued Abroad; A $9.5 billion pollution lawsuit against Chevron could clarify the reach of racketeering law”: Paul Barrett of Bloomberg Businessweek has [this report](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-05-16/supreme-court-may-weigh-big-weapon-for-u-s-companies-sued-abroad).

Posted at [10:24 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71624) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Former Minn. Supreme Court Justice Alan Page on life, education, football and the law”: Minnesota Public Radio posted [this lengthy audio segment](https://www.mprnews.org/story/2017/05/16/gary-eichten-and-alan-page) online yesterday.

Posted at [10:20 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71623) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Supreme Court Justice Sounds Alarm On Speech, Religious Liberty”: Mark Abrams of CBS Philly has [this report](http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2017/05/17/supreme-court-justice-sounds-alarm-on-speech-religious-liberty/).

Posted at [10:18 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71622) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Trump’s Justice: Neil Gorsuch will be the enduring symbol of a disastrous presidency.” Mark Joseph Stern has [this jurisprudence essay](http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2017/05/neil_gorsuch_will_be_the_enduring_symbol_of_a_disastrous_presidency.html) online at Slate.

Posted at [9:35 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71621) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“‘Blue slips’ give Democrats power over Trump’s court nominees”: Alex Swoyer of The Washington Times has [this report](http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/may/14/blue-slip-use-watched-for-judicial-nominees/).

Posted at [7:23 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71620) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“John Marshall: Patriot, Statesman, Chief Justice.” Speaking of [the Great Chief Justice](https://www.nps.gov/nr/twhp/wwwlps/lessons/49marshall/49marshall.htm), next Thursday [this exhibit about him](https://constitutioncenter.org/calendar/john-marshall-patriot-statesman-chief-justice) opens at the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia. Thanks to a friend of this blog, I am looking forward to checking-out the exhibit at its opening reception next Wednesday evening.

Posted at [5:42 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71619) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


The Claremont Institute announces its 2017 John Marshall Fellows: You can view the list [at this link](http://www.claremont.org/page/fellowships/2017-john-marshall-fellows/).

Posted at [5:36 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71618) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


What’s going on? This afternoon, in my capacity as appellate counsel for plaintiffs-appellees in the case captioned Martinez v. American Honda Motor Co., I filed [this answer in opposition](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/pdf/MartinezVsHondaAnswerInOppToApplForReargument051717.pdf) to Honda’s [application for reargument](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/pdf/MartinezVsHondaApplForReargument050317.pdf).

As noted in [this earlier post](http://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/041917.html#071328), on April 19, 2017 a unanimous three-judge panel of the [Pa. Superior Court](http://www.pacourts.us/courts/superior-court/) issued [an unpublished, non-precedential memorandum opinion](http://www.pacourts.us/assets/opinions/Superior/out/J-A21015-16m.pdf) affirming the trial court’s judgment in plaintiffs’ favor.

Posted at [5:27 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71617) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Justice tells seminary grads religious liberty under threat”: The Associated Press has [this report](http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_SUPREME_COURT_ALITO_GRADUATION?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT).

Posted at [5:09 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71616) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Fit to Be Tied: When Appellate Courts Are Evenly Divided.” Yesterday’s edition of The Legal Intelligencer, Philadelphia’s daily newspaper for lawyers, contained [this month’s installment](https://t.co/yQimWxPz8Z) of my “Upon Further Review” column.

Here’s a fun fact on the occasion of this blog’s 15th birthday, recently celebrated. I originally came up with “How Appealing” as a possible name for my monthly Legal Intelligencer column, which started way back in December 2000. The publication’s then-editor in chief chose a different title, leaving “How Appealing” available to serve as this blog’s title since May 6, 2002.

Posted at [4:44 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71615) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Not the 25th amendment”: Eric Posner has [this blog post](http://ericposner.com/not-the-25th-amendment/).

Posted at [1:33 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71614) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“UC Irvine law dean Erwin Chemerinsky named dean of Berkeley’s law school, will begin July 1”: Chris Haire of The Orange County Register has [this report](http://www.ocregister.com/2017/05/17/uc-irvine-law-dean-erwin-chemerinsky-named-dean-of-berkeleys-law-school-will-begin-july-1/).

And Evan Sernoffsky of The San Francisco Chronicle reports that “[Erwin Chemerinsky named dean of Berkeley Law](http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Erwin-Chemerinsky-named-dean-of-Berkeley-Law-11152951.php).”

Update: At his “Election Law Blog,” Rick Hasen has a post titled “[A Few Words About Erwin Chemerinsky, Leaving as UCI Law Dean](http://electionlawblog.org/?p=92573).”

Posted at [1:11 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71613) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


15 years of “How Appealing” — reader mail: Today’s email is from U.S. District Judge, and [nominee](https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/03/21/president-donald-j-trump-announces-intent-nominate-judge-amul-r-thapar) to the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit](http://www.ca6.uscourts.gov), [Amul R. Thapar](https://www.fjc.gov/history/judges/thapar-amul-roger) ([E.D. Ky.](http://www.kyed.uscourts.gov/)):

The blog truly is a service to those of us on the bench. My colleagues and I really appreciate it. Judges regularly talk about how valuable a resource it is. Congratulations and thank you!

Judge Thapar, thank you for this very kind email. It was a pleasure to meet you, and to get to spend some time with you and several of your colleagues from that district court, at last year’s Sixth Circuit conference. I will post another reader email tomorrow.

Posted at [1:05 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71612) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Trump’s values are abhorrent to the Federalist Society of conservative lawyers. That doesn’t stop them from helping him.” Henry Farrell has [this entry](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2017/05/17/trumps-values-are-abhorrent-to-the-federalist-society-of-conservative-lawyers-that-doesnt-stop-them-from-helping-him/) at the “Monkey Cage” blog of The Washington Post.

Posted at [12:54 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71611) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“For Voting Rights Advocates, Court Decision Is ‘Temporary Victory'”: Michael Wines has [this article](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/16/us/for-voting-rights-advocates-court-decision-is-temporary-victory.html) in today’s edition of The New York Times.

Posted at [12:50 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71610) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“November races for statewide judicial elections set”: Karen Langley of The Philadelphia Inquirer has [this report](http://www.philly.com/philly/news/pennsylvania/Judges-races-Pennsylvania-primary.html).

Posted at [12:44 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/05/17/#71609) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

# Top 10 Biglaw Firm Decides One Round Of Raises Isn't Enough
## Gotta keep up with the Cravaths of the world.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 2, 2022 at 1:01 PMMarch 2, 2022 at 12:39 PM
20
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/sidley-re-raise-22/&text=Top%2010%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Decides%20One%20Round%20Of%20Raises%20Isn’t%20Enough)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/sidley-re-raise-22/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/sidley-re-raise-22/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Why settle for one round of raises in 2022, when you can issue two?

That’s what Sidley Austin — a firm that took in $2,462,935,000 in gross revenue in 2020, making it number 6 on the Am Law 100 — is doing. Less than a week ago, the firm issued associate raises, but then [Cravath went ahead and upended](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/cravath-raises-22/) the emerging compensation consensus. Accordingly, Sidley’s latest round of raises will match the Cravath standard and put the firm back at the top of the salary heap.

The new salary grid at Sidley:



And like many of their peer firms, the raises will be retroactive to January 1 and will hit bank accounts in March. Read the full memo [on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/sidley-re-raise-22/2/)

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# Morning Docket: 10.04.18
## * The FBI's completed its superficial Kavanaugh report and there's only one copy. Senators will take turns reading it in one-hour shifts. Is America out of toner? [[Business Insider](https://www.businessinsider.com/brett-kavanaugh-fbi-report-ready-senators-read-1-hour-shifts-2018-10)] * Relatedly, former clerks are now calling for a thorough FBI investigation of Kavanaugh. [[National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/2018/10/03/3-former-kavanaugh-clerks-want-thorough-fbi-investigation/)] * New York will investigate the president for [tax avoision](https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=images&cd=&ved=2ahUKEwjv9tqK6-zdAhVB4VMKHfGYA00QjRx6BAgBEAU&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.funnyjunk.com%2FJoker%2Bhas%2Bhis%2Bpriorities%2Bstraight%2Ffunny-pictures%2F4943500%2F99&psig=AOvVaw1tQGbLCVxdvfXFxyosj9xi&ust=1538744190533955). [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1089237/trump-empire-taxes-to-face-scrutiny-by-ny-nyc)] * Spider-Man gets law degree. [[Legal Cheek](https://www.legalcheek.com/2018/10/law-student-dresses-up-as-spider-man-to-accept-his-degree/)] * How are law firms so profitable? [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/10/03/law-firms-are-more-profitable-than-ever-how-are-they-doing-it/)] * Federal judge halts immigration crackdown because, you know, racism from the administration. [[Courthouse News Service](https://www.courthousenews.com/judge-blocks-trump-from-killing-protections-for-300000/)] * Daily reminder that the Big 4 are coming. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/10/04/big-four-dominate-as-law-firm-alternatives-press-their-brands/)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)

# 70 Percent Of New Partners Are Dissatisfied With Their Job
## Despite the promotion, new partners can find themselves hurting financially.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 21, 2018 at 11:01 AMNovember 21, 2018 at 9:43 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/70-percent-of-new-partners-are-dissatisfied-with-their-job/&text=70%20Percent%20Of%20New%20Partners%20Are%20Dissatisfied%20With%20Their%20Job)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/70-percent-of-new-partners-are-dissatisfied-with-their-job/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/70-percent-of-new-partners-are-dissatisfied-with-their-job/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Biglaw partnership is often viewed as the promised land — after working through the years-long gauntlet of associateship, when a hardworking attorney finally makes it to partner, it seems to all the world that they’ve finally “made it.” But as with many a long-sought-after goals, the reality falls short of the dream.

According to ALM’s [New Partner Survey](https://legalcompass.intelligence.alm.com/#/surveydetail/62/methodology) of 425 attorneys recently elevated to partnership, over [70 percent said they were dissatisfied](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/11/19/some-new-partners-are-troubled-by-perceived-bias-in-the-workplace/) with at least some part of their new position. But what exactly do they have to complain about?

Well, a lot of things, as it turns out. A lot of these newly minted partners said bias was a source of concern, with 9.6 percent saying gender bias was causing dissatisfaction with their job. Another 10.1 percent cited with cronyism as an issue; 1.4 percent said racial bias was a problem; less than 1 percent pointed to sexual orientation bias; and 3.1 percent said age bias was the cause of dissatisfaction.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
But the areas that cause the greatest consternation for new partners — over 10 percent responded they were “not at all satisfied” in each of these areas — were work-life balance, compensation, and training of partnership. As one survey respondent said:

“It was like they said, ‘Congratulations! The rules just changed, but we are not going to tell you what they are,’” one respondent, a third-year partner, said.

The real jaw-dropping number was the [71 percent who are disappointed with compensation](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/11/19/new-partners-dont-know-what-to-expect-after-promotion-survey-shows/). Far from being a huge payday, some new partners actually found themselves seeing a cut in their compensation:

One respondent said they were disappointed to be “treated as a glorified associate for purposes of compensation and bonus (and, thanks to the midyear associate raises, I’ll make less than most senior associates this year).”

All of a sudden, despite the promotion, these attorneys can find themselves hurting financially:

Another said that buying shares, along with lower-than-expected pay and an end to performance bonuses, had placed a strain on finances. “It’s really depressing and demoralizing to get a promotion and then to have to put your family on a strict monthly budget,” that respondent said.

Getting that brass ring isn’t as great as it seems.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. # 5 Issues On The Minds Of Managing Partners
## "Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown" -- or manages a law firm in 2020.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onFebruary 4, 2020 at 12:18 PMFebruary 4, 2020 at 10:26 AM
62
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/5-issues-on-the-minds-of-managing-partners/&text=5%20Issues%20On%20The%20Minds%20Of%20Managing%20Partners)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/5-issues-on-the-minds-of-managing-partners/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/5-issues-on-the-minds-of-managing-partners/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Via Getty Images.)

“Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown,” in the [famous words](https://www.phrases.org.uk/meanings/uneasy-lies-the-head-that-wears-the-crown.html) of Shakespeare. Applied to the world of law firms, it could be translated as follows: “It’s not easy being a managing partner.”

Managing partners have a lot on their minds these days. And last Thursday, at a lively panel at the annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association (NYSBA), five law firm leaders let us into their world.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Skillfully moderated by my colleague [Craig Brown](https://www.laterallink.com/team/craig-brown/), Managing Principal of Bridgeline Solutions (Lateral Link’s temporary staffing arm), the panel featured [Daniel Connolly](https://bracewell.com/people/daniel-s-connolly), Managing Partner of the New York office of Bracewell; [Louis DiLorenzo](https://www.bsk.com/people/louis-p-dilorenzo), Managing Member of the New York office of Bond, Schoeneck & King; [Ronald Shechtman](https://www.pryorcashman.com/lawyers/ronald-h-shechtman.html), Managing Partner of Pryor Cashman; [Marc Landis](https://www.phillipsnizer.com/marc-landis), Managing Partner of Phillips Nizer; and [Richard Scarola](http://szslaw.com/attorney-profiles/#scarola), Managing Member of Scarola Zubatov Schaffzin. The featured firms run the gamut in terms of size from Bracewell, a Biglaw firm with [400 or so lawyers](https://www.law.com/law-firm-profile/?id=38&name=Bracewell-LLP); Pryor Cashman, a midsize firm with [just under 200 attorneys](https://www.pryorcashman.com/about-us/pryor-cashman-llp-about-us.html); and Scarola Zubatov Schaffzin, a boutique with [a dozen lawyers](http://szslaw.com/attorney-profiles/).

What did the panelists discuss? Here are some highlights (with thanks to Jack Newsham of Law.com for his [excellent write-up](https://www.law.com/newyorklawjournal/2020/01/30/from-succession-planning-to-office-space-law-firm-leaders-discuss-industry-concerns/)).

1. Managing millennials.

Like it or not, in less than a decade, millennials will make up [about 75 percent of law firm staff](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/millennials-are-a-dominant-force). So managing partners need to know how to manage millennials (and it won’t be long before millennials themselves are managing partners of major firms, since the oldest millennials are approaching 40).

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
According to Daniel Connolly of Bracewell, there is some truth to the view that millennials value work-life balance more than their predecessors. Sabbaticals, family time, and flexible-work arrangements all appeal to millennials — and, to be honest, who can blame them? But in a client service business, this does have implications for the business aspects of law firms — a topic the panel also tackled.

2. Developing business.

It’s harder and harder to be a “service partner” in this day and age. Ronald Shechtman said that at Pryor Cashman, 40 percent of partners originate $1 million or more in business, and two-thirds of partners originate $500,000 or more. While the need for a $4 million or $5 million book of business [may be exaggerated](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/01/28/how-much-business-do-you-really-need-to-make-a-lateral-move/), firms definitely want partners who can at least “pay for themselves.”

3. Keeping up the culture.

In the words of Shechtman, “The greatest management challenge for our firm is to maintain the culture that we have.” And I suspect that many managing partners would agree with him.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Of course, “culture” will vary from firm to firm (although every firm will claim to be “collegial”). At Pryor Cashman, for example, collaboration is key — which translates into a culture that values presence in the office. The firm also has low leverage, a partner to nonpartner ratio of about 1:1, which Shechtman credits for the firm’s strong retention.

But other firms have very different cultures, and they also manage to succeed. For example, an increasing number of Biglaw firms accommodate [working remotely](http://www.abajournal.com/magazine/article/biglaw_remote_flexible_workplace_telecommute), which can help firms attract and retain talent (e.g., lawyers with significant family responsibilities).

4. Planning for the future.

Law firms are, to their credit, increasingly focused on succession planning. So it should come as no surprise that the topic came up at the managing partner panel.

Some firms have a mandatory retirement age, which they believe helps encourage (or even forces) older lawyers to transition business to the next generation. At the same time, in an age where people are living longer and healthier lives, some older lawyers can and want to remain very active.

Bracewell balances these considerations by having what Daniel Connolly described as a “mandatory but discretionary” retirement age — which encourages lawyers to make way for the next generation, but allows for some exceptions. All older partners must develop a plan for handing off business to their younger colleagues, however, regardless of when they plan to retire.

5. Advancing diversity.

The lack of diversity on the panel did not go unnoticed. As Marc Landis of Phillips Nizer put it, “You’re looking at five white men.”

But how — and how quickly — will law firms change on this front? Alas, that is the subject for another, much longer discussion.

[David Lat](https://davidlat.com/), the founding editor of Above the Law, is a [writer](https://davidlat.com/writing/), [speaker](https://davidlat.com/speaking/), and [legal recruiter at Lateral Link](https://www.mainspringlegal.com/team/david-lat/), where he is a managing director in the New York office. David’s book, [Supreme Ambitions: A Novel](http://bit.ly/SupremeAmbitions) (2014), was described by the New York Times as “the most buzzed-about novel of the year” among legal elites. David previously worked as a federal prosecutor, a litigation associate at Wachtell Lipton, and a law clerk to Judge Diarmuid F. O’Scannlain of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. You can connect with David on [Twitter (@DavidLat)](http://bit.ly/2BMTF1R), [LinkedIn](http://bit.ly/2E9v0tq), and [Facebook](http://bit.ly/2nxIENN), and you can reach him by email at [dlat@laterallink.com](mailto:dlat@laterallink.com).

# MoFo Revamps Its Partnership: The Number Of Equity Partners Drops 25 Percent As The Firm's Nonequity Ranks Soar
## The (equity) partnership is shrinking.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 29, 2019 at 4:16 PMApril 1, 2019 at 11:15 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/03/mofo-revamps-its-partnership-the-number-of-equity-partners-drop-25-percent-as-the-firms-nonequity-ranks-soar/&text=MoFo%20Revamps%20Its%20Partnership:%20The%20Number%20Of%20Equity%20Partners%20Drops%2025%20Percent%20As%20The%20Firm’s%20Nonequity%20Ranks%20Soar)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/03/mofo-revamps-its-partnership-the-number-of-equity-partners-drop-25-percent-as-the-firms-nonequity-ranks-soar/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/03/mofo-revamps-its-partnership-the-number-of-equity-partners-drop-25-percent-as-the-firms-nonequity-ranks-soar/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Partnership at Morrison & Foerster doesn’t mean what it used to. In a statement to ALM about the firm’s 2018 financial performance, MoFo revealed that they’ve made some big changes to the way partners at the firm get compensated:

“Morrison & Foerster modified its partnership compensation structure at the start of 2018,” said the firm’s statement. “The modifications followed a year of consultation with our partners and was made to ensure that the compensation model further advances the strategic needs of the firm.”

And, as [Law.com reports](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/03/25/partner-compensation-changes-at-morrison-foerster-lead-to-equity-partner-drop-pep-surge/), this has led to a shift in which partners count as equity partners (defined as partners who get more than 50 percent of their total compensation from profit draws):

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
As a result of the compensation modifications, the firm’s equity partner count fell to 167 from 224—a 25 percent decline. Meanwhile, the firm’s nonequity partner ranks swelled 50 percent to 129 from 86. The firm’s total partner count, including equity and nonequity partners, fell 4.5 percent.

And that means that even as revenue dropped in 2018 — down 1.9 percent to $1.04 billion — their profits per equity partner (PEP) are up to just under $2 million, compared with $1.74 million the year before. That’s some fancy math-ing to keep your numbers looking pretty.

Despite what seems like some pretty straightforward de-equitization, Larren Nashelsky, chair of the firm, has a different take:

Despite the drop in equity partnership, Larren Nashelsky, Morrison & Foerster’s New York-based chairman, said in an interview the firm had not “de-equitized” partners as part of the compensation review. “There has been no radical change in our partnership,” Nashelsky said. “It is really, over the last few years, strengthening and improving the performance of the partnership and our leverage and profitability.”

Nashelsky said the firm isn’t looking to compete with other Biglaw firms:

“We are not in an economic arms race with other firms,” Nashelsky said. “We have a special place at Morrison & Foerster. We take stock of a lot of things when we think about the kind of firm we want to be. Financial performance is one of them. So is giving back. So is excellence in lawyering. So is diversity and inclusion, and so is representing the world’s leading companies.”

But the firm had its best PEP performance in 2018.

# Morning Docket: 10.16.18
## * Valparaiso celebrated earlier in the week after reaching an agreement to send its beleaguered law school to Middle Tennessee. Tennessee's education officials have killed the idea of hosting another middling law school with extreme prejudice. [[Chicago Tribune](http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/post-tribune/news/ct-ptb-vu-law-denied-st-1016-story.html)] * Ninth Circuit judge displays deliberate ignorance in what appears to be a looming decision to keep college athletes out of court. [[Courthouse News Service](https://www.courthousenews.com/ninth-circuit-unlikely-to-revive-athletes-quest-for-pay-from-ncaa/)] * Whenever you doubt the stupidity of humanity, remember people accused of global financial fraud tend to email each other explicit descriptions of what they're doing. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1092407/deutsche-traders-knew-libor-rigging-was-illicit-jury-told)] * Boies Schiller will act as special prosecutor in the Joe Arpaio appeal in what should be the easiest appellate layup ever. [[The Recorder](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/10/15/boies-schiller-partner-tapped-as-special-prosecutor-in-arpaio-appeal/)] * Republican judge dismisses lawsuit against Republican politician. [[Huffington Post](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/stormy-daniels-lawsuit-donald-trump-defamation_us_5bc52164e4b055bc9478ef04)] * Jeff Sessions tells the Heritage Foundation that he doesn't approve of this idea that courts might consider themselves some kind of "check" or "balance" on the executive branch. [[National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2018/10/15/jeff-sessions-inveighs-against-federal-judges-in-heritage-foundation-speech/)] * Ralph Baxter thinks Biglaw needs to change its business model to succeed. # The Loop Elite: The Go-To Firms Of Chicago
## A handy primer to the top firms in the Windy City.
By [Brian Dalton](https://abovethelaw.com/author/brian-dalton/)  
onJuly 27, 2017 at 4:01 PMSeptember 20, 2017 at 4:44 PM
164
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/the-loop-elite-the-go-to-firms-of-chicago/&text=The%20Loop%20Elite:%20The%20Go-To%20Firms%20Of%20Chicago)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/the-loop-elite-the-go-to-firms-of-chicago/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/the-loop-elite-the-go-to-firms-of-chicago/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[Lake Whillans](http://lakewhillans.com/), a leader in the field of litigation finance, supports innovative entrepreneurs and businesses across the country. Over the past year, Lake Whillans has brought us a series of handy primers on some of the most dynamic and innovative legal markets in the country, including [Silicon Valley](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/the-white-sandal-elite-the-go-to-law-firms-of-silicon-valley/), [Boston](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/rt-128-elite-the-go-to-law-firms-of-boston/), and the “[Wild West](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/the-wild-west-elite-the-go-to-law-firms-of-texas-colorado-and-utah/).” Today, we turn to Chicago, the cultural and economic capital of the Midwest.

Chicago boasts an incredibly diversified economy. The Second City serves as headquarters for a multitude of Fortune 1000 companies, particularly in agribusiness, manufacturing, insurance, logistics, healthcare, and pharmaceuticals. Of course, Chicago is also a vital center for financial markets, with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange being the largest futures exchange in the world. Meanwhile, the city has also quietly become a hub for fast-growing private companies in the tech sector. All this economic vibrancy drives the nation’s third-largest legal market, a multi-layered ecosystem with the home and satellite offices of the best Biglaw firms, regional powerhouses, specialist boutiques, and smaller firms with deep local roots and thriving practices.

The Go-To Law Firms of Chicago can not only handle every transactional need, they do anything from construction litigation to patent prosecution. Engaging these firms can help companies of all sizes — from tech startups to multi-nationals — avoid or contain problems. However, in the event of litigation, Lake Whillans can step in as a source of capital to fund legal expenses as well as for corporate purposes.

1. Best Firm for Helping You Build Your Real Estate Empire: [Thompson Coburn LLP](http://www.thompsoncoburn.com/offices/chicago)

Few Chicago firms can rival the real estate law experience of Thompson Coburn LLP. Boasting a deep knowledge of commercial lending markets, the firm’s lawyers are adept at advising clients in all phases of the real estate transaction lifecycle. The firm’s real estate practice handles matters for clients of all sizes, from small landlords and tenants, to regional retailers, to Fortune 500 companies, in nearly all jurisdictions across the country. No matter what your real estate law question is, the team at Thompson Coburn has the answer.

2. Best Firm For Transportation and Logistics: [Hinshaw & Culbertson LLP](http://www.hinshawlaw.com/locations-offices-Chicago.html)

Chicago is the key transportation hub in the country. Hinshaw & Culbertson’s transportation law practice represents businesses in the trucking, shipping, cargo, aviation and railroad industries, as well as every category of client in the complex world of logistics. The firm’s attorneys have hundreds of jury trials under their belts in the transportation field. Whether it’s an insurance coverage dispute, worker’s comp claim or regulatory hurdle, Hinshaw & Culbertson keeps on trucking.

3. Best Firm for Handling Commodity Pools: [Sidley Austin](https://www.sidley.com/en/us/)

A city with its own mercantile exchange, Chicago has long been synonymous with commodities. With Chicago roots dating all the way back to 1866, Sidley Austin offers one of the most comprehensive commodity pool services in the city, if not the world. The firm helped its clients develop some of the first-ever public commodity pools in the 1970s, and has gone on to represent hundreds of publicly offered and privately placed commodity pools since then. With key players in the Chicago office, Sidley’s global commodity pools practice group has the skills to tackle any issue their commodity pool clients face, from legal structuring and formation, to regulatory matters, to exchange listings.


4. Best Firm to Salvage Your Reputation in a Crisis: [Riley Safer Holmes and Cancila](http://www.rshc-law.com/)

The Windy City has seen its fair share of scandals over the years, but your company shouldn’t be one of them. When your reputation is on the line, Riley Safer is the firm you want in your corner. With a dedicated Risk, Reputation, and Crisis Management practice group, these lawyers have seen it all. Aimed at avoiding costly lawsuits before they start, the team routinely helps companies develop enterprise risk management policies that effectively mitigate risk. If things still go wrong, Riley Safer specializes in a broad range of crisis control and reputation management services that will help keep your company afloat and minimize any fallout.

5. Best Firm for Clients in the Food and Agribusiness Sector: [McDermott Will & Emery](https://www.mwe.com/en/locations/chicago)

Established in 1934 as the firm’s first office, the Chicago outpost of McDermott Will & Emery remains the flagship for many of the firm’s key practice areas, and it offers one of the most highly renowned food, beverage and agribusiness practices in the world. Representing more than 500 clients across all aspects of the production chain — including growers, manufacturers, and restaurateurs — no firm offers deeper knowledge of the industry. Whether you’re a local producer or a global conglomerate, the firm’s attorneys are unrivaled in all areas of agribusiness law, including domestic and international regulations, cross-border transactions and farm subsidies.

6. Best Firm for White-Collar Defense: [Jones Day](http://www.jonesday.com/investigationswhitecollardefense/)

The Windy City has a long tradition of freewheeling and bruising political and business cultures, with no shortage of demand for top-flight white collar criminal defense work. Jones Day’s Investigations and White Collar Defense practice boasts deep experience in defending both companies and individual clients in the full range of white collar criminal matters, from fraud and insider trading allegations to alleged breaches of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and the Anti-Kickback Statute. Many of the Jones Day white collar practitioners gained invaluable insight and experience through service in senior positions in the DOJ and US Attorney’s offices, including the practice group leader Ted Chung, who runs the department out of the Chicago office.


7. Best Firm For Construction Litigation: [Shipley Law Group Ltd.](http://www.shipleylawgroup.com/aop/#construction_litigation)

“Chicago reinvents and rebuilds itself every day,” proclaims the site for Shipley Law Group and the firm embodies that slogan by helping clients maneuver through the complex world of Illinois construction law. Founder Robert Shipley draws on a nearly four-decade track record of successful representations of construction industry clients, including architects, suppliers, engineers, and developers involved building Chicago’s hotels, convention centers, hospitals, and major developments.

8. Best Firm to Handle Shareholder Disputes: [Novack and Macey, LLP](http://www.novackmacey.com/)

With a depth of experience that belies its small size, this versatile boutique shop is no stranger to major shareholder litigation. Whether you’re in the minority or the majority, the firm’s lawyers will fight relentlessly to do defend your rights as shareholder. No issue is too complex for this team of trial experts, who have handled everything from shareholder oppression issues, to claims of self-dealing, to corporate voting battles. It’s no surprise that Chicago companies consider Novack and Macey the go-to firm for avoiding a crippling shareholder dispute.

9. Best Firm for Sports Law: [Katten Muchin Rosenman LLP](https://www.kattenlaw.com/Chicago)

Chicago has long been synonymous with sports, and Katten’s sports and sports facilities group is the go-to team for some of sports’ heaviest hitters across the globe, from leagues and franchise owners, to broadcasters and advertisers, to promoters and corporate sponsors. For example, Katten has served as outside general counsel for both the Chicago White Sox and Chicago Bulls since its acquisition by Jerry Reinsdorf in the 1980s, and it also serves as outside general counsel for an impressive lineup of NBA, MLB and MLS franchises. Whether you’re dealing with financing, facing complex regulatory issues or building a stadium, Katten is the firm you want in your corner.


10. Best Firm for When You Actually Find Yourself in a Courtroom: [Bartlit Beck Herman Palenchar & Scott LLP](http://www.bartlit-beck.com/)

When it comes to jury trials, no one does it better than Bartlit Beck. Founded in Chicago in 1993 by a group of preeminent Biglaw trial attorneys, this firm is not afraid to see the inside of a courtroom. In fact, the firm’s lawyers average a remarkable 10 trial days per year, thus justifying Bartlit Beck’s self- description as “a firm of trial lawyers, not litigators.” Such is the firm’s courtroom prowess that it is often brought in to join a case on the eve of trial, when clients are most urgently in need of deeply experienced trial counsel. Bartlit Beck maintains its pool of talent by hiring only a select few elite candidates each year, more than 60% of whom are former Federal judicial clerks.

11. Best Firm for Educational Institutions : [Schiff Hardin](http://www.schiffhardin.com/)

Chicago is obviously one of America’s great university towns and Schiff Hardin’s Educational Institutions practice offers schools full-spectrum guidance through the myriad legal challenges they face. Schiff Hardin offers educational institution clients — including University of Chicago and Northwestern — the effective guidance they need to navigate the complex web of federal and state laws concerning everything from labor and employment matters to real estate transactions to financing.


12. Best Firm to Defend You in a Pharma Claim: [Goldman Ismail Tomaselli Brennan & Baum LLP](http://www.goldmanismail.com/contact-office-chicago.html)

Pharmaceuticals are undeniably a huge part of the Chicago legal landscape, and when it comes to defending pharmaceutical and medical device companies against product liability claims, no one does it better than Goldman Ismail. The firm has represented industry giants like Merck and Bayer in some of the country’s most complex multi-district litigations, and it is adept at handling every aspect of a mass tort or stand-alone pharma case. Regardless of your product or device, the lawyers at Goldman Ismail will develop the scientific theory necessary to persuasively present your case.

13. Best Firm for Planning (or Avoiding) a Reorganization: [Jenner & Block](https://jenner.com/about/chicago)

Founded by three lawyers in 1914, Jenner & Block has grown to be one of Chicago’s largest law firms. Jenner’s bankruptcy acumen is undeniable, as exemplified by the appointment of Anton Valukas, the firm’s then-chairman, as examiner in the Lehman Brothers Holdings bankruptcy, the largest such case in U.S. history. Lawyers at the firm routinely represent all parties in Chapter 7 and Chapter 11 cases, including distressed companies, lenders, creditors and trustees. And when things go to court, the firm’s attorneys have the dispute resolution chops necessary to handle even the most complex of bankruptcy litigations.

14. Best Firm to Represent Your Luxury Goods Company: [Barack Ferrazzano Kirschbaum & Nagelberg LLP](http://www.bfkn.com/)

Today’s digital marketplace has introduced new challenges to the luxury retail industry, and no firm knows how to handle them better than Barack Ferrazzano. With a unique practice group dedicated to serving the luxury industry, the firm has partnered with some of the world’s most iconic luxury brands over the last three decades. Whether you deal in fashion, jewelry or spirits, the team at Barack Ferrazzano has the know-how to guide you through the often-complicated domestic and international waters of the luxury goods sector.

15. Best Firm for Patenting Your Next Great Product or Device: [K&L Gates](http://www.klgates.com/chicago-united-states-of-america/)

With a Chicago office dating back to 1888, K&L Gates has a long history of helping Midwestern businesses protect their innovations and ideas across the globe. The firm has more than 225 lawyers — approximately 100 of whom are registered patent lawyers and hold advanced technical degrees — dedicated to establishing and enforcing their clients’ intellectual property rights. Whether you need to secure your first patent or prosecute infringers, this firm has the skill to handle even the most complex of patent matters.


16. Best Firm to Independently Advise the Board of Directors: [Winston & Strawn LLP](http://www.winston.com/en/where-we-are/north-america/chicago.html)

It’s hard to find deeper Chicago roots than those at Winston & Strawn LLP, which was founded in the Windy City in 1853. Among the firm’s many specialties is advising boards of directors, particularly in the areas of executive compensation and corporate governance. Well-versed in all aspects of securities law, Winston’s lawyers also offer executive and director training in a range of compliance issues. For boards looking to retain independent counsel, this is the firm to call.

17. Best Firm For Startups: [goodcounsel](http://www.mygoodcounsel.com/)

goodcounsel is a small law firm of “innovators for innovators,” openly bucking the conventions of a tradition-bound profession. Founded by erstwhile entrepreneur Ken Obel, goodcounsel offers efficient, inventive and tech-savvy legal counsel to entrepreneurial clients. goodcounsel prefers to operate on a fixed-fee basis, charging for value rather than time. The firm offers a wide range of services on a project basis for growing companies, including contract drafting and negotiation, investment rounds and entity formation documentation.


18. Best Firm to Help You Conquer the Healthcare Industry: [Latham & Watkins LLP](https://www.lw.com/offices/chicago)

One of the nation’s premiere law firms, Latham & Watkins brought its nationally renowned healthcare law expertise to Chicago in 1982. Unrivaled in its expertise when it comes to legal issues affecting the healthcare industry, the firm has handled some of the largest global transactions in the field. Regardless of your role in the healthcare sector, this is the firm to call for everything from complex contracts to large-scale litigations to regulatory investigations.

19. Best Firm to Handle Your Infrastructure Transactions: [Mayer Brown](https://www.mayerbrown.com/locations/Chicago/)

Founded in Chicago in 1881, Mayer Brown boasts one of the world’s most renowned domestic and cross-border infrastructure practice groups, with several of the team’s key players resident in the Windy City. The firm handles all aspects of infrastructure transactions, including public-private design and construction projects, infrastructure financing, and infrastructure investment fund formation. Their infrastructure clients span all sectors of industry, from mass transit and airports, to bridges and parking, to energy and water. When you need knowledgeable counsel for your next infrastructure deal, this is the firm to call.

20. Best Firm for Lobbying Congress in Your Favor: [Locke Lord](http://www.lockelord.com/thefirm/offices/chicago)

This venerable national law firm has long been lauded as one of the country’s political lobbying powerhouses. Windy City corporations can enjoy the firm’s deep public policy expertise thanks to the experienced lawyers in its Chicago office who are part of Locke Lord’s dedicated public law and policy practice group. With a proven record of guiding clients through the complex legislative and regulatory waters, the firm represents companies across all industries. When you need your voice heard on Capitol Hill, Locke Lord delivers.

21. Best Firm to Defend Your Product Liability Lawsuit: [Swanson, Martin, & Bell, LLP](http://www.smbtrials.com/)

The Circuit Court of Cook County is a notoriously inhospitable forum for defendants in product liability lawsuits. Fortunately for manufacturers of firearms, medical devices, automobiles, power tools, or any other product at the center of recurrent litigation, the product liability team at Swanson, Martin & Bell can draw on a wealth of experience to craft cost-effective strategies to secure a favorable business resolution. Not only are the SMB attorneys courtroom veterans, they also have a strong track record advising the legal and financial departments of Fortune 500 companies on cutting edge budgetary strategies involved in product liability defense.

# The Money Is Really Moneying At This Biglaw Firm!
## Wow, much money! Very capital!
By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)  
onMarch 1, 2022 at 12:33 PMMarch 1, 2022 at 11:57 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/the-money-is-really-moneying-at-this-biglaw-firm/&text=The%20Money%20Is%20Really%20Moneying%20At%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/the-money-is-really-moneying-at-this-biglaw-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/the-money-is-really-moneying-at-this-biglaw-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Nothing brightens the first of the month quite like more money in your pocket.

Latham & Watkins, which grossed a whopping $4,333,763,000 gross revenue in 2020, continues its trend of money moves by matching Cravath’s freshly released salary scale. (But that’s not all — check out the cash that 9th years will be receiving… $425K!)



The raises will be retroactive to January 1 and will hit bank accounts in March. While they may in second place on the American Lawyer’s 2021 Am Law 100 ranking, this type of money is second to none. Who is next to follow (law) suit?

(Turn to the next page to see the Latham & Watkins memo.)

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

We like hearing about salary increases almost as much as you enjoy spending them. As soon as your firm’s memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Salary & Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

Chris Williams became a social media manager and assistant editor for Above the Law in June 2021. Prior to joining the staff, he moonlighted as a minor Memelord™ in the Facebook group [Law School Memes for Edgy T14s](https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=10222912314148913&set=p.10222912314148913&opaqueCursor=AboVBPzRKh4loie1LupyI7ltSvsaUWxURlMk_338xXb_BPhzMNPHbWfVDUsOyUH1mfvHQ4Bsipef989J-V0OyqhMZzHPafTw49vttxDh_no8xymRSSUssmh47qTzHAc13R0wzk8nPhgSylnSAYcBNbHjYDqZDqy5r0f7PwzCZw9T-0cakKMIin3XI0O8R5H5OJGAu4kJjGPAoZpgL6woU9lwoHiAjxAwAlpmdlyt6vHLJ1TVn2srkC3G4qBW5ANthJ_YNT3BUPCu2vu1ZIxiqYwXGLfMIxQR4cllUaB0Cja74ln1FHs3n-xyHe6MDtxln0-F4QJchox9nCaivB_xmSxw3FduERhPebhWj1MKJ20jeucGZ64jY6DdUn2d87dVgNlFE5qHvNEtfMpoEKx1096oFfqbZ9s71YVsbXxLIsRiiW54eLp4R7z3WHAKu8v8xeLIZt86UVU1iOaSlJ0n5tT3_VonQT6n2F0sIUSLY272cI-yjWxaUIr0Qj-1NQDFFcn9dkq8pYV2-o0M3LK2Qhr9LKt-Bk4MTGUZCkb4Kw6mgDmRCux3nhJqd2hdLd8LgTA).  He endured Missouri long enough to graduate from Washington University in St. Louis School of Law. He is a former boatbuilder who cannot swim, [a published author on critical race theory, philosophy, and humor](https://www.academia.edu/33296970/Lets_Be_Frank_Parrhesia_and_the_Black_Comedic_Tradition), and has a love for cycling that occasionally annoys his peers. You can reach him by email at [cwilliams@abovethelaw.com](mailto:cwilliams@abovethelaw.com) and by tweet at [@WritesForRent](https://twitter.com/WritesForRent).

# Probably Not How You Should Talk To Pregnant Associates: A Biglaw Play In Four Acts
## What are they teaching associates these days?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 10, 2018 at 3:00 PMDecember 12, 2018 at 12:44 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/probably-not-how-you-should-talk-to-pregnant-associates-a-biglaw-play-in-four-acts/&text=Probably%20Not%20How%20You%20Should%20Talk%20To%20Pregnant%20Associates:%20A%20Biglaw%20Play%20In%20Four%20Acts)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/probably-not-how-you-should-talk-to-pregnant-associates-a-biglaw-play-in-four-acts/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/probably-not-how-you-should-talk-to-pregnant-associates-a-biglaw-play-in-four-acts/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
UPDATE: Some of the timeline below is a bit off — after you finish this story, [check out this update](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/more-details-from-the-offensive-simpson-thacher-pregnant-email/).

Corporate deals can get chippy, but what this dustup between associates at Simpson Thacher and Freshfields really makes you wonder if transactional attorneys need to be taking fewer cues from the investment bankers on how to conduct themselves in polite society.

This exchange takes place in the Chinese market, and while one might think there are cultural differences at play, both associates involved attended U.S. law schools and the one who comes out of the gate also went to undergrad in the U.S., so they should both have a good sense of the standards of professionalism their firms expect.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Standards that, for example, don’t include emailing everyone on the deal something like this — from the Simpson associate to the Freshfields associate:



Both associates involved are women and, among friends, women are inclined to joke about “pregnancy brain.” But “among friends” carries a lot of water in that sentence. It’s not something to be blasted to everyone working a deal to undermine a rival associate.

We’re not publishing the associates’ names because we don’t know if there’s an innocent explanation for these emails — a friendly tweaking gone wrong perhaps. That said, “Don’t let your pride get in the way of this deal” certainly doesn’t sound friendly.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
For her part, the Freshfields associate responds (and we think this is a direct response — the timeline on the emails is a little hard to follow):



Well, that’s a lot better than “You shut your goddamned mouth before I come down there and fuckstart your head” which is the response I’d have expected from most of my female colleagues over the years if someone had pulled this. Still, this would have been a good time to can the snark and respond with more shocked indignance. This associate hasn’t done anything wrong, but certainly by taking the bait, she’s escalated the fight.

And, since she didn’t slam the brakes on this, here’s what she gets back from Simpson:



###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
The emails cut off here, probably because the Simpson associate got slapped unconscious by a pregnant lady.

Thankfully, at the end of this chain, a Freshfields partner steps into the situation to put a stop to it.



With so many people on this chain, it’s encouraging that someone took the helm here before it got any worse. Sometimes associates aren’t in the best position to stand up for themselves — they have limited authority and a real concern that they could undermine the deals they’re working on. That’s why addressing discrimination has to be everyone’s job.

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joe@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news.

# Biglaw Partner Is Having A Blast Working From Home With His 11 Kids
## 'It’s barely controlled chaos. Lots of noise,' he says.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 23, 2020 at 2:14 PMMarch 23, 2020 at 2:11 PM
22
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-partner-is-having-a-blast-working-from-home-with-his-11-kids/&text=Biglaw%20Partner%20Is%20Having%20A%20Blast%20Working%20From%20Home%20With%20His%2011%20Kids)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-partner-is-having-a-blast-working-from-home-with-his-11-kids/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-partner-is-having-a-blast-working-from-home-with-his-11-kids/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Everyone is more forgiving about background noise on conference calls. I used to have a quick trigger finger for the mute button, and that seems a lot less necessary now. Clients have been tremendously patient about hearing my 2-year-old in the background.

—  [Michael Williams](https://www.kirkland.com/lawyers/w/williams-michael-f-pc), a litigation partner at Kirkland & Ellis, commenting on his [unique work-from-home situation](https://www.law.com/2020/03/20/how-does-he-do-it-kirkland-partner-at-home-with-11-kids/) during the coronavirus outbreak. Williams has 11 children, ages 2 to 20, and they all do work together around the same dining room table. “The silver lining of the COVID-19 shutdown is that we eat three meals a day together now,” he says.

# LOCKED UP! Former Dewey CFO Jailed Because He Can't Pay Fine
## The judge found he 'willfully failed to pay his fine.'
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 15, 2018 at 3:00 PMNovember 15, 2018 at 2:12 PM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/locked-up-former-dewey-cfo-jailed-because-he-cant-pay-fine/&text=LOCKED%20UP!%20Former%20Dewey%20CFO%20Jailed%20Because%20He%20Can’t%20Pay%20Fine)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/locked-up-former-dewey-cfo-jailed-because-he-cant-pay-fine/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/locked-up-former-dewey-cfo-jailed-because-he-cant-pay-fine/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When former Dewey & LeBoeuf chief financial officer [Joel Sanders was sentenced](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/no-jail-time-for-convicted-dewey-cfo/) to a million-dollar fine and 750 hours of community service rather than jail time for [his conviction](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/holy-crap-dewey-know-who-was-convicted-of-felony-charges/) on two felony fraud charges and a misdemeanor count of conspiracy, you probably thought he got off easy, at least compared with the jail time the prosecution was seeking. But today, Sanders was taken into custody when he couldn’t make the payment on his first installment on the fine.

New York State Supreme Court Justice Robert Stolz found that Sanders “willfully failed to pay his fine.” Sanders had argued he was unable to make his first of three yearly payments on the fine without dire financial consequences for his family. However the judge rejected this argument, saying, “I find the claimed inability to pay here not credible.” In support of his decision, Justice Stolz cited some of the assets Sanders has, as reported by Law.com:

But at a hearing on Thursday, Stolz noted that Sanders owns, outright, a house in Long Island worth at least $650,000, and has about $850,000 in equity on an oceanfront condominium in Miami Beach, Florida that’s worth around $1 million. The judge also pointed out that Sanders and his wife have leases on “two high-end cars”—one an Audi and the other a Mercedes-Benz.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Sanders can be incarcerated for up to a year until he pays the full $1 million fine. Sanders’s attorney, DLA Piper partner Christopher Oprison, expressed displeasure at the decision, “It’s a travesty. I think it’s completely unjust. This is the last person you want to put away and send away in prison, and I think it’s really unfortunate it came to this.”

But Oprison still noted they’re going to try to pay the fine.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

# Davis Polk Associates Better Get Their Butts To The Office If They Want Their Full Bonus
## Want your money? Get to the office.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 24, 2023 at 1:13 PMMarch 25, 2023 at 10:55 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/davis-polk-associates-bonus-office-attendance/&text=Davis%20Polk%20Associates%20Better%20Get%20Their%20Butts%20To%20The%20Office%20If%20They%20Want%20Their%20Full%20Bonus)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/davis-polk-associates-bonus-office-attendance/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/davis-polk-associates-bonus-office-attendance/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The end of the first quarter is around the corner, and Biglaw firms will no longer tolerate associates not abiding by their mandatory office attendance policies. We’ve recently learned that another elite Biglaw firm — a compensation leader, in fact — will be considering office attendance in their bonus decisions for 2023.

If Davis Polk associates in New York want their full bonus this year, they’ll have to go to the office three days a week, per their revised policy.

Davis Polk first instituted their mandatory Tuesday-Thursday [attendance policy](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/top-biglaw-firm-returns-to-the-office-with-mandatory-tuesday-thursday-attendance/) about one year ago, but due to recent events, we’re wondering how well that’s been working out.

Sources tell us that the firm revised the in-office attendance segment of its handbook as of March 6, 2023, to reflect the fact that associate bonuses may be impacted by inconsistent and infrequent office attendance. Specifically, “[f]ailure by any lawyer to comply with the operative in-office attendance policy may adversely affect the lawyer’s performance evaluation and result in disciplinary action, including but not limited to the withholding or reduction of a discretionary bonus (emphasis added), in accordance with applicable law.” A screenshot of DPW’s new policy can be seen below:



We’ve heard that members of the firm’s professional development team have been calling associates with poor office attendance to tell them about the new bonus policy. A tipster at the firm tells us, “DPW of course does totally lockstep bonuses without even an hours minimum but apparently is threatening to dock bonuses of big billers if they choose to do that billing at home.” Sheesh!

The new normal for associates is starting to look a whole lot like the old normal for associates, with their firms in complete control. If they want their full bonuses — and if they want to avoid being seen as a candidate for stealth layoffs — it’s officially time to head on back to the office.

Now that Davis Polk has implemented this new policy, will other Biglaw firms follow? If your firm is linking bonuses to office attendance let us know. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Attendance) or text us (646-820-8477). Thanks for your help.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).
