# Biglaw Firm Shunned Office Attendance Mandates... Now 'Expecting' Two Days A Week
## There was a dream that was home.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onApril 16, 2024 at 3:27 PMApril 18, 2024 at 11:34 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/biglaw-firm-shunned-office-attendance-mandates-now-expecting-two-days-a-week/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Shunned%20Office%20Attendance%20Mandates…%20Now%20‘Expecting’%20Two%20Days%20A%20Week)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/biglaw-firm-shunned-office-attendance-mandates-now-expecting-two-days-a-week/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/biglaw-firm-shunned-office-attendance-mandates-now-expecting-two-days-a-week/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(via Getty Images)

The KattenFlex program planted a stake in the legal landscape, bucking the trend of “mandatory office creep,” by adopting a policy that elevated flexibility allowing practice groups and individual professionals the freedom to figure out a hybrid path that works for them. As the firm declared at the time “[it ‘doesn’t feel right’ to mandate that everyone must come into the office a set number of days](https://katten.com/american-lawyer-features-kattenflex-workplace-return-program).”

So… Katten just informed attorneys that they need to come in twice a week.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Today, we announce an update to KattenFlex: beginning May 1, the firm expects attorneys to work from a Katten office a minimum of two days per week. Additionally, the firm continues to expect that regardless of where you are working, all professionals are generally available during regular business hours and as needed to meet client demands after hours.

It’s understandable to see this as a retreat from the firm’s earlier laissez-faire policy because it is, in fact, a retreat. Every time a firm blasts out a new revision to bring people back to the office, it will rankle attorneys who thought they were going to be treated as true professionals. But in an industry marching toward [four-day attendance policies](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/simpson-thacher-4-days-in-office/) and [paranoid surveillance](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/biglaw-firms-three-day-office-workweek-descending-into-paranoid-surveillance/), let’s focus on what Katten is still getting right.

Katten stresses that the expectation is not a mandate or requirement, but an effort to set some consistency. The program amendment is a mere two days, offering attorneys more freedom from commuting than peer firms. And the mandate does not set specific days to come in, continuing to give groups and their attorneys the flexibility to choose. Ultimately that’s more important than the number of days required. Attorneys want to be able to say, “I can come in, but, for me, I need to be home on Wednesdays because that’s the day I have to handle school car pool” or whatever it is.

The announcement even stresses “we are keeping the ‘flex’ in KattenFlex, a key component of Katten’s supportive workplace environment.”

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
That said, the announcement might be too loosey-goosey.

However, select legal departments or practice groups may choose to require or designate specific days for in-office attendance or for a specific number of days per week. Your legal department or practice group will provide additional guidance.

This is the sort of exception that risks swallowing the rule. Katten’s memo suggests that leadership intends to work with practice groups to prevent groups from invalidating the spirit of the rule, but it still extends an awful lot of latitude to partners itching to bring everyone back in.

Fully remote work was never going to take hold across Biglaw. The stakes are too high, the importance of providing practical training to young associates too engrained, and the partner egos too brittle. But firms that protect attorney flexibility will earn themselves a consistent advantage in recruitment and retention.

Katten’s new policy walked back some of core features while claiming to preserve others. How much of a retreat this turns out to be is now up to the implementation.

# The Raises Just Keep On Coming For The Best Of The Biglaw Elite
## Another big player is on board with the new associate compensation scale.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 18, 2018 at 2:19 PM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-raises-just-keep-on-coming-for-the-best-of-the-biglaw-elite/&text=The%20Raises%20Just%20Keep%20On%20Coming%20For%20The%20Best%20Of%20The%20Biglaw%20Elite)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-raises-just-keep-on-coming-for-the-best-of-the-biglaw-elite/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-raises-just-keep-on-coming-for-the-best-of-the-biglaw-elite/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Good news for associates at Fried Frank — the firm has announced that they are increasing associate salaries in the New York, D.C., and London offices (only leaving out the firm’s very small and very senior Frankfort office). The salary increases, ranging from $10,000 – $25,000, depending on class year, will also be accompanied by special summer bonuses, which range from $5,000 to $25,000, based on seniority.

This summer has been a fascinating one for associate compensation. It started with Milbank — Thrillbank, if you will — shocking the Biglaw world with new raises. This was matched by Simpson Thacher, which went over the top with special bonuses. Cravath finally came to play, slightly increasing salaries from the Milbank scale for senior associates. All of which resulted in the franken-[Milbank](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/new-york-to-190k-no-cravath-didnt-make-the-first-move/)/[Simpson](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/biglaw-giant-matches-associate-raises-plus-special-summer-bonuses/)/[Cravath](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/cravath-hath-spoken-and-beats-milbank-for-senior-associates/) scale, which Fried Frank (and any firm that fancies itself at the top of the Biglaw heap) has now met.

The numbers for your viewing pleasure:

# Biglaw Associate Takes On USA Gymnastics In New Lawsuit
## Former Olympian turned Biglaw associate has filed suit against USA Gymnastics.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 1, 2018 at 12:35 PMNovember 1, 2018 at 12:45 PM
52
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/biglaw-associate-takes-on-usa-gymnastics-in-new-lawsuit/&text=Biglaw%20Associate%20Takes%20On%20USA%20Gymnastics%20In%20New%20Lawsuit)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/biglaw-associate-takes-on-usa-gymnastics-in-new-lawsuit/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/biglaw-associate-takes-on-usa-gymnastics-in-new-lawsuit/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Tasha Schwikert-Warren

Olympic Bronze medalist and current Biglaw associate, Tasha Schwikert-Warren, along with her sister, former U.S. gymnast Jordan Cobbs, filed a pair of lawsuits against USA Gymnastics and officials of the organization for fraud and racketeering earlier this week. The allegations stem from USA Gymnastics’ employment of convicted sexual predator Larry Nassar. Nassar, [as you’ll recall](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/in-an-utterly-unsurprising-move-judge-throws-the-book-at-larry-nassar/?rf=1), was sentenced to 40 – 125 years in prison for taking advantage of his position as U.S. national gymnastics team doctor by sexually abusing over 100 women and girls. In handing down the hefty sentence, the judge did not want Nassar to be a free man ever again, saying, “I’ve just signed your death warrant,” and, “You do not deserve to walk outside of a prison ever again.”

Schwikert-Warren is [an associate](https://www.hollandhart.com/tschwikert-warren) in the real estate and construction practice group at Holland & Hart. She previously completed a clerkship in the Eighth Judicial District Court in Nevada for Judge Joanna S. Kishner and Judge Mark R. Denton. Schwikert-Warren came forward with her story of the abuse she suffered at the hands of Nassar last month, [telling ABC News ](http://abcnews.go.com/US/olympian-tasha-schwikert-abused-larry-nassar-manipulated-supporting/story?id=58592690)that she was abused more than 100 times between 2000 and 2005.

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[As reported by](https://www.law.com/2018/10/31/big-law-associate-sues-usa-gymnastics-over-sex-abuse-scandal/) Law.com, part of the motivation for the lawsuit was legal action being taken against former USA Gymnastics officials:

On Oct. 29, Schwikert-Warren and Cobbs filed a pair of fraud and racketeering complaints against USA Gymnastics in Los Angeles Superior Court. In a press conference that same day, both women said they were motivated to tell their stories as a result of the recent arrest in Tennessee of former USA Gymnastics president Stephen Penny Jr. A Texas grand jury has indicted Penny on charges of evidence tampering in an investigation into Nassar.

The complaint alleges USA Gymnastics failed to provide a “culture of accountability and transparency” that could have stopped the reign of Nassar’s abuse.

“I am outraged at watching what’s been happening at USA Gymnastics,” Schwikert-Warren told reporters this week at a press conference in Los Angeles. “It’s like watching a perpetual circus of horribles.”

# This Biglaw Firm Won't Require Attorneys To Work A Set Number Of Office Days
## Yet another firm bids farewell to the pre-pandemic status quo.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 22, 2021 at 4:16 PMJuly 22, 2021 at 2:08 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/this-biglaw-firm-wont-require-attorneys-to-work-a-set-number-of-office-days/&text=This%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Won’t%20Require%20Attorneys%20To%20Work%20A%20Set%20Number%20Of%20Office%20Days)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/this-biglaw-firm-wont-require-attorneys-to-work-a-set-number-of-office-days/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/this-biglaw-firm-wont-require-attorneys-to-work-a-set-number-of-office-days/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
After Labor Day, we will not—as a matter of ordinary course—require a particular number of days in the office. Instead, we will continue to trust everyone to work with their practice group leaders and managers to determine the best workplace balance for providing exceptional service to our clients, strengthening our cultural glue and ensuring all members of our teams are trained, integrated and positioned for continued growth and success.

— An excerpt from a memo sent by Katten CEO Noah Heller and firm chairman Roger Furey, regarding [the firm’s plans for a return to the office](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/07/21/katten-wont-mandate-a-set-number-of-days-in-office/) in the wake of the pandemic. Heller and Furey noted that the firm’s policy will provide associates with “the flexibility to continue to balance the demands of [their] professional and personal lives, and it will help us retain and attract the best talent in the industry and position our firm for even more success.”

# The UK Top 50: The Wealthiest Biglaw Firms Across The Pond
## Biglaw means big money in the UK.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)

1

We all know that Biglaw firms in America did well — really, really well — in 2021, but what about their Biglaw counterparts across the pond in the United Kingdom? How did they fare when it came to their financial metrics? Thankfully, the latest edition of the UK Top 50 is out, which measures gross revenue, revenue per lawyer, and profits per equity partner, just like the Am Law 100.

Collectively, as noted by [Law.com International’s](https://www.law.com/2022/09/12/uk-top-50-ranked-by-revenue-fee-income-surges-despite-headwinds-292-128665/) Hannah Walker in her summary of the data, the UK Top 50 achieved their strongest increase in total revenue since the Great Recession, up by 10.9% (compare this with 2020’s numbers, where average total revenue was up 5.9%); a 2.8% increase in average revenue per lawyer (£406,100); and a 7.7% increase in profits per equity partner (£939,600). Here are more details on the positive results from the UK:

Almost half—19 firms—posted double digit revenue increases, compared with 11 in the previous year. Only four firms posted a fall in revenue, compared with 10 in the previous year.

However the U.K. firms’ growth lags that of their U.S. counterparts, with the [Am Law 100](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/04/26/the-2022-am-law-100-report/) recording a collective revenue growth of 14.8% for 2021, led by Kirkland & Ellis and Latham & Watkins.

The turnover increase did not translate into such a significant rise in average profit per equity partner across the firms, as they grappled to keep costs under control amid a rampant pay war for junior talent.

# Biglaw New York Mainstay Opens Up Its First West Coast Office
## Welcome to Cali!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 13, 2018 at 3:15 PMDecember 13, 2018 at 2:12 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/biglaw-new-york-mainstay-opens-up-its-first-west-coast-office/&text=Biglaw%20New%20York%20Mainstay%20Opens%20Up%20Its%20First%20West%20Coast%20Office)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/biglaw-new-york-mainstay-opens-up-its-first-west-coast-office/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/biglaw-new-york-mainstay-opens-up-its-first-west-coast-office/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Looks like Willkie Farr & Gallagher is going to give West Coast living — or at least lawyering — a try. The Biglaw firm, headquartered in New York City since 1888, has announced they’re opening an office in Silicon Valley. They’ve tapped two new lateral hires, partners Tiffany Lee and Matthew Berger, formerly of Paul Hastings, to lead the new office which will also be staffed with Willkie attorneys relocating from New York.

Lee will be the managing partner in Silicon Valley. Her practice mainly focuses on M&A, private equity financing, and intellectual property which she does for clients primarily in the tech industry. Berger was formerly the global chairman of the technology transactions practice at his old firm, Paul Hastings.

In a statement, Lee said she was excited about the opportunities at Willkie:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
“With Willkie’s Silicon Valley arrival and the natural synergies between our broad technology transactions experience and highly regarded corporate, M&A and private equity capabilities, we are excited for a greater and more value-added collaboration with current and prospective clients, local, domestic and abroad,” Lee said in a statement.

For their part, Willkie is jazzed about the chance to extend their brand into Cali:

“We are very excited that [Lee] and [Berger] have decided to join our expanding technology-focused corporate, M&A and private equity platforms and are bringing their extensive and highly regarded technology transactional expertise to our newest office,” Willkie co-chairman Gordon Caplan said in a statement.

“Willkie goes where the highest quality talent and energy is located [and] we have a longstanding and extensive client base in Palo Alto, and California more generally,” he added.

Congratulations to Lee and Berger on their latest career move.

# Another Biglaw Firm Expands Their Parental Leave With New Benefits
## Fried Frank steps up their parental leave game.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 29, 2018 at 1:32 PMNovember 30, 2018 at 7:34 PM
9
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/another-biglaw-firm-expands-their-parental-leave-with-new-benefits/&text=Another%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Expands%20Their%20Parental%20Leave%20With%20New%20Benefits)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/another-biglaw-firm-expands-their-parental-leave-with-new-benefits/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/another-biglaw-firm-expands-their-parental-leave-with-new-benefits/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The trend of Biglaw firms updating their [parental leave policy](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/parental-leave/) to be gender neutral and more generous continues. Along those lines, Fried Frank recently announced exciting new changes to their leave policies.

Last year Fried Frank renamed their policy to reflect the gender-neutral nature of the program, as “maternity leave” as a term is rapidly becoming antiquated. Now, in order to better reflect the gender-neutral nature of the policy, the firm is also removing the primary caregiver requirement for participation, meaning all new parents — whether they are new parents via birth, adoption, or fostering of a child — are able to enjoy the same paid time off. They’ve also expanded the amount of time off to 12 weeks (it was previously 10 weeks for primary caregivers, five for everyone else) and the policy applies to all attorneys and business services professionals.

As part of the policy, and this was true in the previous iteration as well, birthing mothers are also eligible for disability leave in addition to their parental leave. Parents can split their leave in two blocks of time within the first 12 months, and any accrued time off can be used to supplement their leave.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
All of this is in addition to the firm’s existing benefits designed to assist their employees including a breast milk delivery service for breastfeeding employees traveling for work, back up childcare, nursing rooms in each office, reduced work schedules for associates who are new parents for up to six months, and access to a 24/7 wellness program. All of which help make the challenging balancing act of a new family member with life in Biglaw just a little bit easier.

Kudos to the firm on the expansion of their leave policy. Let’s hope more firms get on board with the trend.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

# Stroock Is Talking To Another Am Law 100 Firm About Merging — But It’s Not ‘Exclusive’
## They’re both keeping their options open… but what if this is Stroock’s only option to make it through the year?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 22, 2023 at 11:15 AMSeptember 26, 2023 at 8:40 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/stroock-is-talking-to-another-am-law-100-firm-about-merging-but-its-not-exclusive/&text=Stroock%20Is%20Talking%20To%20Another%20Am%20Law%20100%20Firm%20About%20Merging%20—%20But%20It’s%20Not%20‘Exclusive’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/stroock-is-talking-to-another-am-law-100-firm-about-merging-but-its-not-exclusive/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/stroock-is-talking-to-another-am-law-100-firm-about-merging-but-its-not-exclusive/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Stroock has been leaking lawyers like a sieve ever since it broke up with Nixon Peabody, but it finally got rid of its baggage (i.e., its pension problems), and just like that, the firm has matched up with another eligible bachelor on the merger market.

According to a report from the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/09/21/pillsbury-becomes-latest-firm-to-begin-merger-dance-with-stroock/), Stroock’s latest law firm hookup is Pillsbury Winthrop, and the pair have signed a non-exclusive letter of intent to merge. Pillsbury brought in $751,491,000 gross revenue in 2022, putting it at No. 65 in the most recent Am Law 100 ranking, and if the proposed tie-up is successful, it will bring an international presence to Stroock. Here’s more from [Am Law](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/09/21/pillsbury-becomes-latest-firm-to-begin-merger-dance-with-stroock/):

“We consider all growth opportunities presented to us, including potential lateral groups and combinations. We are currently evaluating opportunities with Stroock,” the firm said in a statement. “We signed a non-exclusive LOI to help frame the discussion. The process is ongoing.”

A spokesperson for Stroock confirmed the talks with Pillsbury but declined to comment on the LOI. “We continue to explore various opportunities,” the spokesperson said. “We can confirm that we are talking with Pillsbury about potential synergies.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
While both firms are keeping their options open, hopefully those “synergies” work out, because industry insiders and even former Stroock employees are unsure if the firm will be able to survive through the end of the year without merging with another firm.

Best of luck to both firms — and especially to Stroock — as they embark upon this possible merger journey.

# DLA Piper Plans To Dump Tons Of Bonus Cash On Associates
## Associates are *so happy* about this!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 26, 2021 at 3:48 PMMarch 26, 2021 at 7:08 PM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/dla-piper-special-bonus-2021/&text=DLA%20Piper%20Plans%20To%20Dump%20Tons%20Of%20Bonus%20Cash%20On%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/dla-piper-special-bonus-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/dla-piper-special-bonus-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This time last year, Biglaw firms were still figuring out how to adapt to remote working environments thanks to the pandemic, but now, Biglaw firms are figuring out when (or whether) they’ll announce additional rounds of special bonuses to reward all of their attorneys’ hard work over the course of the past 12 months. Top-ranked firms have been announcing [Davis Polk bonus](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/davis-polk-spring-special-bonus-2021/) matches left and right. Which one is it this time?

DLA Piper — a firm that came in at No. 3 on the most recent Am Law 100 ranking, with $3,112,130,000 in gross revenue in 2019 — thrilled associates with its special bonus announcement today. The firm has fully matched the bonus scale announced by Davis Polk. In case you’ve forgotten what that looks like, DLA’s bonus scale can be seen below (the full memo is available on the [next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/dla-piper-special-bonus-2021/2/)):



[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Here are some instant reactions from associates at the firm, who are all quite happy:

You love to see it. Associates are thrilled and feel like the firm has redeemed itself. DLA stepped up after just one week of special bonus mania and even before Cravath. Couple this with the recent standardization of market salaries across all US offices, and we really are competitive again.

DLA FULL MATCH!!!!! Very happy they moved fast on this after how they botched 2020 special bonuses. This news, coming on the same day I received my first paycheck at Cravath scale (because I’m in a secondary market), kiboshes my current efforts to lateral.

Bonuses at DLA Piper will be paid half in May and half in September to all associates in good standing. Congratulations to all!

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. # Norton Rose Fulbright Lays Off Associates, Cuts Salaries Amid COVID-19 Upheaval
## A billion dollars in revenue doesn't stop COVID-19 layoffs.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 16, 2020 at 4:00 PMApril 16, 2020 at 6:22 PM
25
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/norton-rose-fulbright-lays-off-associates-cuts-salaries-amid-covid-19-upheaval/&text=Norton%20Rose%20Fulbright%20Lays%20Off%20Associates,%20Cuts%20Salaries%20Amid%20COVID-19%20Upheaval)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/norton-rose-fulbright-lays-off-associates-cuts-salaries-amid-covid-19-upheaval/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/norton-rose-fulbright-lays-off-associates-cuts-salaries-amid-covid-19-upheaval/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This is big. After all, only 10 firms in the entire country are bigger than Norton Rose Fulbright; they had $1,969,315,000 in 2018 gross revenue, making them number 11 on the Am Law 100 ranking. But despite that size and might, the firm still finds themselves in need of cost-cutting measures because of COVID-19. And not just salary cuts, which many firms see as a prudent move to help with cash flow as opposed to a permanent change in compensation, but we understand layoffs are also part of their austerity plan.

So, let’s get to the details we know. Above the Law tipsters report Norton Rose Fulbright announced a 15 percent salary cut in the U.S. The compensation cut applies to all salaried non-partner attorneys and staff, except those making under $50,000. As of now, the pay cuts will start April 30 and are expected to last through September 30. As a tipster noted, “However, they’ve not cut their summer program nor ceased hiring new attorneys. There is no reduction in required billable hours or change in bonus metrics.”

We’ve also received information from multiple sources that the austerity measures at the firm have included layoffs — characterized by one tipster as “the WORST PART.” According to those at the firm, both staff and attorneys were impacted by these layoffs, but exactly how many folks find themselves out of work was something Norton Rose refused to disclose.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
The firm is already in the process of [implementing four-day work week](https://www.law360.com/articles/1263817/norton-rose-greenlights-four-day-week-for-select-staff), on a temporary basis, for some of its eligible staff in Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

Jeff Cody, Norton Rose Fulbright’s US Managing Partner, made the following statement about the cost-cutting measures:

“As we all know, the coronavirus is having an unprecedented effect on markets and businesses around the world and in the US. The extent of the virus’ impact on the legal industry is unclear at this time, but the road ahead appears challenging. In light of these conditions, US leadership believes it is prudent to take steps to address this uncertainty and ensure that our law firm emerges healthy and strong. Although difficult, we have asked our attorneys and staff to accept a temporary reduction in compensation. We will work aggressively throughout the balance of the year in the hope that we can lessen the impact of these salary reductions. We also have made discrete reductions in our US work force as part of our plan to safeguard the future of our more than 1,600 lawyers and staff.”

Best of luck to those who find themselves out of work in the middle of a pandemic.

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

If you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Layoff Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the layoff alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each layoff, salary cut, or furlough announcement that we publish.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. # Big Money Awaits Lawyers Who Lateral In Hot 2022 Market
## It's a new year, but there's still a war for lawyer talent going on.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 3, 2022 at 4:46 PMJanuary 3, 2022 at 3:07 PM
43
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/big-money-awaits-lawyers-who-lateral-in-hot-2022-market/&text=Big%20Money%20Awaits%20Lawyers%20Who%20Lateral%20In%20Hot%202022%20Market)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/big-money-awaits-lawyers-who-lateral-in-hot-2022-market/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/big-money-awaits-lawyers-who-lateral-in-hot-2022-market/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I don’t see things slowing down at all. All the soft indicators we look at are suggesting that the current market will continue.

— [Kate Reder Sheikh](https://www.mlaglobal.com/en/people/kate-reder-sheikh?byconsultantorauthor=kate-reder-sheikh), a recruiter with Major, Lindsey & Africa, commenting during an interview with Reuters on the [white-hot lateral market for associates and partners that broke out in 2021](https://www.reuters.com/legal/legalindustry/legal-talent-war-that-broke-out-2021-shows-no-sign-slowing-down-2021-12-30/) after the first year of the pandemic. In response, Biglaw firms across the country have raised salaries and handed out bonuses of all kinds to either entice lawyers to stay put or join their firms. “It’s hard to leave a firm when there is a bunch of money on the table,” Sheikh said.

# Clifford Chance Lassos Latham Partners As It Expands Into Texas
## Yeehaw! The Magic Circle firm's new office deep in the heart of Texas.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 5, 2023 at 2:16 PMJune 5, 2023 at 1:33 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/clifford-chance-texas/&text=Clifford%20Chance%20Lassos%20Latham%20Partners%20As%20It%20Expands%20Into%20Texas)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/clifford-chance-texas/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/clifford-chance-texas/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Hot on the heels of the [megamerger announcement](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/shearman-sterling-allen-overy-merger/) made between Allen & Overy and Shearman & Sterling, yet another Magic Circle firm is trying to stake a larger claim here in America.

Clifford Chance — a firm that came in at No. 2 in the 2021 UK 100 ranking with $2,711,508,000 gross revenue — currently offices in New York and Washington, D.C., but will soon be opening its third U.S. firm in Houston, Texas.

[Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/clifford-chance-to-launch-houston-office-with-10-partner-team) has additional details on the firm’s plans:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The move to Houston is aimed at bolstering the firm’s 400-lawyer global energy and infrastructure practice—with an eye on the transition to renewable energy sources—and fueling US growth, a key long-term strategy. …

“We are seeing around the world so much going on with the energy transition,” Sharis Arnold Pozen, regional managing partner for the Americas, said in an interview. “In Houston, that’s the hub for energy work and the energy transition.”

The firm has hired Latham & Watkins partners Jonathan Castelan and Trevor Lavelle for its Houston office, and several Clifford Chance partners will be relocating from New York and Paris to join their colleagues there.

“Expanding our global energy offering in Houston, the world’s leading energy hub, reflects our strategy to build out our capability in geographies and sectors critical to our clients’ future growth,” Global Managing Partner Charles Adams noted in a press release. “Energy transition is a priority for our clients and our depth of knowledge across technologies and jurisdictions in this sector positions Clifford Chance to add real value to businesses pursuing a sustainable path.”

Congratulations to Clifford Chance as the firm heads to Texas to conquer the growing energy industry.

# Thanks To COVID-19, Biglaw Summer Associates Are Very Concerned About Job Security, Money
## What matters most to summer associates? Here's some insight.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 22, 2020 at 12:15 PM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/thanks-to-covid-19-biglaw-summer-associates-are-very-concerned-about-job-security-money/&text=Thanks%20To%20COVID-19,%20Biglaw%20Summer%20Associates%20Are%20Very%20Concerned%20About%20Job%20Security,%20Money)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/thanks-to-covid-19-biglaw-summer-associates-are-very-concerned-about-job-security-money/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/thanks-to-covid-19-biglaw-summer-associates-are-very-concerned-about-job-security-money/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The summer of 2020 was pretty strange for summer associates. Thanks to the coronavirus crisis, law students who normally would have been wined and dined by their Biglaw firms all summer long instead found themselves at home, anxiously experiencing law firm life through their computer screens. But for all that was unusual about this past summer, law students made the most of it. According to a new survey from the American Lawyer, this year’s crop of summer associates were generally satisfied with their virtual experiences in Biglaw. One summer associate at an Am Law 50 firm perfectly summarized law students’ experience in this sentence: “It was the best you could do in this situation.”

So, which Biglaw firms were on top during COVID-19’s summer of sadness? Unfortunately, the summer associate program rankings are yet another thing that the novel coronavirus has taken from us. Although there is no formal ranking this year, the following firms stood out above the rest in the minds of summer associates:

- Proskauer Rose
- Morgan, Lewis & Bockius
- Shearman & Sterling
- Dorsey & Whitney
- Clifford Chance
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
So, what were this year’s summers most concerned about, all things COVID considered? It’s all about the money, honey (and mental health, too). After having witnessed their programs be shortened and austerity measures rolled out across the Biglaw landscape, about half (48.4 percent) of the 2,500 summers polled by Am Law said job security was their top concern. (Last year, summers cared the most about work-life balance. It’s nice to remember when things were so simple, isn’t it?)

Some summers were properly peeved that their paychecks were discounted based on their shortened programs because they were “counting on being paid” for the full length of the program — after all, other firms did paid full freight, despite cutting weeks from their summers’ schedules.

“This probably saved them some money (and maybe they needed it), but after talking with the other summers, I think most of us were really financially hurt by this. Overall, I am not sure that move was worth it because it really hurt the summers financially and it hurt their confidence in the firm,” the associate continued.

That sentiment played out in respondents’ assessments of their firms’ finances. Most of those assessments were glowing. But summers who faced pay cuts had a gloomier perspective. Some saw the reduced compensation as a reflection of their firm’s ability to weather a storm—or, in this case, a pandemic.

On top of pay issues, summer associates were having trouble staying busy. Not only were their hours down — they worked 42 hours a week and billed 20 hours on average, compared to last year, when they worked 43 hours a week and billed 24 hours on average — but the quality of the work just wasn’t up to snuff. Summers were not only working virtually, but they were doing simulated work on fake deals. Why’s that? To protect associate hours. Eeek.

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Next up, we’ve got mental health, which is an understandable concern for people who were working alone and feeling isolated during a pandemic. Around 48 percent of respondents said they were concerned about their mental health, up from 39 percent last year. Thankfully, summer associates say their firms have taken their mental health seriously and given it proper focus during these tough times. Seventy-one percent said that mental health seemed like a priority at their firms during the pandemic (up from 63 percent last year).

What do these Biglaw firms have in store for their 2020 summers — most of whom have already received offers of permanent employment — in the future? COVID-19 isn’t quite done with the legal profession yet, so we’ll have to wait and see. In the meantime, congratulations to all of the firms that earned the respect and appreciation of their summer associates.

# Top Biglaw Firm's Chair Beseeches Lawyers, Staff To Get Vaccinated
## This Biglaw firm deeply cares about its employees and wants to keep them as safe as possible.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 3, 2021 at 1:45 PMAugust 3, 2021 at 1:27 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/top-biglaw-firms-chair-beseeches-lawyers-staff-to-get-vaccinated/&text=Top%20Biglaw%20Firm’s%20Chair%20Beseeches%20Lawyers,%20Staff%20To%20Get%20Vaccinated)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/top-biglaw-firms-chair-beseeches-lawyers-staff-to-get-vaccinated/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/top-biglaw-firms-chair-beseeches-lawyers-staff-to-get-vaccinated/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
For those of you who have yet to receive a vaccine, we implore you to re-consider. For some, we realize that you have a bona fide medical issue or a sincerely held religious belief that prevents you from being vaccinated. Others may have concerns grounded in uncertainty about the risks of the vaccine or its benefits. For those members of our community, we urge you to seek the advice of a medical professional, a spiritual guide or a trusted advisor with whom you can explore this very important decision in depth, with this virulent and aggressively contagious strain of COVID-19 in mind. We are deeply committed to your safety and it’s not an understatement to say that your life, and the lives of others, may depend on your decision.

— An excerpt from a memo sent by [Julie Jones](https://www.ropesgray.com/en/biographies/j/julie-h-jones), chair of Ropes & Gray, concerning the firm’s new vaccination mandate, effective August 9. From that date on, only fully vaccinated individuals may enter any of the firm’s U.S. offices or attend any of the firm’s events and gatherings, no matter their location. Ropes will disable the IDs of unvaccinated employees so they will be unable to gain access to the office, making it the second firm to take such an action. Jones states that 98 percent of the firm’s lawyers and 90 percent of the firm’s business support team have already been vaccinated. Flip to the next page to read the firm’s memo, in full.

# Welp, It Doesn't Look Like This Biglaw Firm Will Be Matching Spring Special Bonuses
## Don't hold your breath for special bonuses at this firm.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 29, 2021 at 10:42 AMMarch 30, 2021 at 11:15 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/welp-it-doesnt-look-like-this-biglaw-firm-will-be-matching-spring-special-bonuses/&text=Welp,%20It%20Doesn’t%20Look%20Like%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Will%20Be%20Matching%20Spring%20Special%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/welp-it-doesnt-look-like-this-biglaw-firm-will-be-matching-spring-special-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/welp-it-doesnt-look-like-this-biglaw-firm-will-be-matching-spring-special-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Special bonus season is upon us. That means that the top of the Biglaw heap is busy showering its associates with extra cash to say thank you. But when [special bonuses swept](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/biglaw-fall-special-bonus-tracker-which-biglaw-firms-are-handing-out-cash-for-associates-hard-work-during-the-pandemic/) the industry in the Fall of 2020, there was a segment of firms that [went out of their way](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/kirklands-not-giving-special-bonuses-and-associates-are-salty-about-it/) to be clear that bonuses (at least in autumn) were not in the offing. Now that there are more bonuses afoot, firms that aren’t ready to dole out bonuses are also being clear with associates.

The following email was sent to U.S. associates at Magic Circle firm Clifford Chance. A recent video message noted that bonuses were coming, but a follow-up message made clear, that because[ U.S. associates got the fall special bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/magic-circle-firm-hands-out-bonuses-to-make-thanksgiving-truly-magical/), they will not be getting special bonuses in 2021.


Of course, they could always come back and say (particularly as market pressure increases with even more firms deciding to match this new spring bonus scale), JK! Here are more associate bonuses. But given the tone of this email, well, it doesn’t seem likely. UPDATE: Other tipsters at Clifford Chance have reached out to Above the Law to say they’re still hopeful that the firm may make a move to match the market, particularly since the email predates the special bonus momentum. Either way, we’ll be watching to see what happens.

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

# Morning Docket: 09.04.19
## * Just in case no one saw this one coming, LeClairRyan has filed for bankruptcy. The firm owes $15 million to two secured creditors. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/09/03/leclairryan-files-for-bankruptcy-owes-15m-to-unitedlex-venture-lender/)] * Like it or not, the next recession is coming: Some law firms will struggle more than others, and "once this party ends, its going to end very quickly and it’s going to end very severely." [[Big Law Business](https://biglawbusiness.com/struggling-law-firms-may-face-dissolution-risk-in-recession)] * What's wrong with the bar exam? This is what the National Conference of Bar Examiners’ Testing Task Force is taking its sweet time [trying to figure out](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/the-future-of-the-bar-exam/). [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/2019/09/03/ditch-multiple-choice-simplify-the-bar-exam-ideas-abound-on-reforming-the-test/)] * Law school classes come in all sizes, but you may want to think about how yours will affect the attention you'll receive, your social life, your networking opportunities, and most importantly, your ranking. [[Law Admissions Lowdown / U.S. News](https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/law-admissions-lowdown/articles/2019-09-02/what-to-know-about-law-school-class-sizes)] * Thank u, next? Pop star Ariana Grande has filed a $10 million lawsuit against Forever 21 after the store allegedly hired a look-alike model for a social media campaign, rather than Grande herself. [[THR, Esq. / Hollywood Reporter](https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/ariana-grande-sues-forever-21-using-a-look-alike-model-social-media-1236154)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)

# Am Law 100 Firm Slashes Salaries For All, With Up To 50 Percent Cuts For Some
## Salaries will be reduced across the board, by an average of 10 percent.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 28, 2020 at 11:20 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/am-law-100-firm-slashes-salaries-for-all-with-up-to-50-percent-cuts-for-some/&text=Am%20Law%20100%20Firm%20Slashes%20Salaries%20For%20All,%20With%20Up%20To%2050%20Percent%20Cuts%20For%20Some)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/am-law-100-firm-slashes-salaries-for-all-with-up-to-50-percent-cuts-for-some/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/am-law-100-firm-slashes-salaries-for-all-with-up-to-50-percent-cuts-for-some/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

It’s another day in the world of the coronapocalypse, and law firms continue to do whatever they can to cut costs so they can survive when all of this is over. Over the past few months, we’ve seen some of the largest law firms in the world conducting salary cuts, furloughs, and even layoffs — and we don’t think this is going to stop anytime soon.

Littler, the largest employment firm in the world, came in 66th place in the 2020 Am Law 100 rankings with $590,038,000 gross revenue in 2019, but that’s not stopping the firm from slashing salaries across the board.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Equity partners at the firm (“participating shareholders” in Littler lingo) and corporate management will have their salaries reduced by 20 percent as of May 8, while highly compensated nonequity partners (“non-participating shareholders”) and non-attorney senior-level administrative employees with compensation of more than $300,000 will have their salaries reduced by 15 percent on the same date. (These cuts will occur in Mexico and Canada on May 15.)

The rest of the firm will have their salaries reduced by an average of 10 percent on June 5. These are the tiers by which all other non-equity partners, principals, other attorneys, paralegals, and office and corporate administrative employees will have their salaries slashed in about a month from now (Littler’s memo on the next page):

- Up to $50K: 4 percent
- >$50-$75K: 6.5 percent
- >$75-$100K: 9 percent
- >$100-$200K: 11 percent
- >$200-$300K: 13 percent
All other employees who are unable to work remotely due to their job responsibilities will see their pay reduced by 50 percent on June 5, but they’ll be able to tap into their paid time-off balances to make up for the difference.

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

If you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Layoff Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each layoff, salary cut, or furlough announcement that we publish.

# Women Without Support Networks Will Likely Leave Their Law Firms
## Women in the legal profession must help other women so they can survive in Biglaw -- and thrive.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 9, 2016 at 4:00 PM
5
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/women-without-support-networks-will-likely-leave-their-law-firms/&text=Women%20Without%20Support%20Networks%20Will%20Likely%20Leave%20Their%20Law%20Firms)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/women-without-support-networks-will-likely-leave-their-law-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/women-without-support-networks-will-likely-leave-their-law-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
To me, as a female associate at a large law firm, the solution is simple: women need to help other women. If you know another woman has your back, you stay. If you don’t have that support, you leave. Also, giving back to other women when you can is important.

— [Rachel Gezerseh](http://www.jonesday.com/rgezerseh/), an associate at [Jones Day](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/jones-day/), explaining some of the ways she thinks law firms, especially Biglaw firms, can solve their problems having to do with the retention of female attorneys, in an op-ed published at [Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/perspective-in-law-women-need-to-help-other-women/).

# Cadence Counsel And Bluerock Team Up For An Exclusive Search
## Cadence Counsel is working with Bluerock, a leading institutional alternative asset manager based in New York, on an exclusive search for a Real Estate Counsel.
By Cadence Counsel  
onJanuary 28, 2022 at 2:14 PMApril 28, 2022 at 4:03 PM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/cadence-counsel-and-bluerock-team-up-for-an-exclusive-search/&text=Cadence%20Counsel%20And%20Bluerock%20Team%20Up%20For%20An%20Exclusive%20Search)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/cadence-counsel-and-bluerock-team-up-for-an-exclusive-search/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/cadence-counsel-and-bluerock-team-up-for-an-exclusive-search/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A certified Women’s Business Enterprise with over a dozen offices stateside and abroad, [Cadence Counsel](https://cadencecounsel.com/) is the nation’s largest diversity supplier of in-house lawyers. Cadence Counsel recruiters are former practicing attorneys and award-winning consultants who provide executive search and interim attorney placement services, document review staffing, and diversity & development consulting to Fortune 500 law departments, sports franchises, technology organizations, public utilities, and more.

[Inc. magazine recently named Cadence Counsel](https://cadencecounsel.com/inc-5000-names-cadence-counsel-as-one-of-the-fastest-growing-companies-in-america/) to its annual Inc. 5000 list. As the most prestigious ranking of the nation’s fastest-growing private companies, the list represents a unique look at the most successful companies within the American economy. Intuit, Zappos, Under Armour, Microsoft, Patagonia, and many other well-known names gained their first national exposure as honorees on the Inc. 5000.

Cadence Counsel is working with Bluerock on an exclusive search for an experienced transactional Real Estate Counsel. Founded in 2002, Bluerock is a leading institutional alternative asset manager based in New York with regional offices across the United States. Reporting directly to Bluerock’s General Counsel, the successful candidate will assume primary responsibility on the legal side for all of Bluerock’s real estate transactions. The ideal candidate will have 6+ years of legal experience related to real estate acquisitions and financings, and will be a nimble team player adept at building strong, collaborative trust relationships at all levels of the business. If your profile may be a fit for this exciting opportunity, we would be pleased to hear from you.

Primary Responsibilities

- Drafting, reviewing and negotiating transactional documentation in connection with the acquisition and disposition of real estate;
- Drafting, reviewing and negotiating financing documentation in connection with both asset-level and corporate-level financings;
- Collaborating with internal teams and outside counsel on structuring a variety of real estate transactions and joint ventures;
- Coordinating with senior management to resolve issues and facilitate the timely closing of transactions;
- Developing and improving internal processes in connection with the expansion of Bluerock’s portfolio across multiple asset classes;
- Supporting various business groups including acquisitions, accounting, marketing and operations; and
- Overseeing and managing junior team members as well as outside counsel.
Qualifications

- Strong academic background including law degree from a top law school;
- 6+ years of post-JD experience working on real estate acquisitions and related financings, ideally at both a leading Am Law 100 law firm and as in-house counsel in a real estate capacity;
- Strong transactional real estate experience:
- Extensive direct transactional experience across a broad range of real estate asset classes, with particular emphasis on residential and industrial;
- Significant experience in connection with real estate financings, with particular emphasis on credit facilities and agency financings, and in the negotiation and drafting of complex joint venture agreements on behalf of capital partners;
- Experience in the single family residential space (including negotiation of warehouse lines of credit), development deals (including construction financings), and/or the representation of sponsors of multifamily 1031 syndications would be beneficial but not a prerequisite;
- Strong work ethic, highly motivated and proactive;
- Personable and a team player with a desire to contribute to a collaborative work
environment;
- Superior organizational skills and ability to independently manage multiple workstreams;
- Excellent communication, problem-solving and analytical skills;
- Ability to work with all levels of management; and
- Integrity and professionalism.
Location

Bluerock prefers candidates based out of the New York City metropolitan area but will consider remote work for the right candidate.

About Bluerock

Bluerock principals have a collective 100+ years of investing experience and manage multiple well-recognized real estate private and public company platforms. Bluerock has more than $11.5 billion in acquired and managed assets and offers a complementary suite of public and private investment programs, with both short and long-term goals, to individual investors seeking solutions aimed at providing predictable income, capital growth, and tax benefits. In 2021, Bluerock raised over $2.1 billion of new capital across its investment programs.

Bluerock companies are active acquirers of multifamily, industrial and single-family residential real estate assets across the United States. Bluerock companies completed 54 property acquisitions and dispositions with an aggregate purchase price in excess of $2.5 billion in 2021 and completed 107 property acquisitions and dispositions with an aggregate purchase price in excess of $5.5 billion during the three-year period from 2019 to 2021.

If you are interested in learning more, please reach out to either of the recruiters handling the search, [Emma Hepworth](mailto:ehepworth@cadencecounsel.com) or [Ashley McCall](mailto:amccall@cadencecounsel.com).

# As Summer Draws To A Close, Another Biglaw Firm Announces Summer Bonuses
## It may not be enough to call a trend, but there's at least another firm with a summer bonus out there.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onAugust 29, 2019 at 2:14 PMAugust 29, 2019 at 4:00 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/as-summer-draws-to-a-close-another-biglaw-firm-announces-summer-bonuses/&text=As%20Summer%20Draws%20To%20A%20Close,%20Another%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Announces%20Summer%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/as-summer-draws-to-a-close-another-biglaw-firm-announces-summer-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/as-summer-draws-to-a-close-another-biglaw-firm-announces-summer-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Way back in May, the legal world got its first taste of the 2019 round of summer bonuses when [Gunderson stepped up](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/gunderson-announces-summer-bonuses-your-move-am-law-100/) and offered associates a little taste of bonus cash. After a summer pay extravaganza last year that saw associate salaries spike and summer bonuses to boot making for a very, very fine year for attorneys. No one expected a repeat of 2018, but Gunderson’s move seemed to kick off another season of small but appreciated bonuses.

And then… [nothing](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/where-in-the-world-are-your-summer-bonuses/). The legal industry went on radio silence. [Revenue is up](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/law-firm-revenue-is-up-because-were-just-making-people-pay-more-for-less/), yet firms seem much more cautious this year. Whether that stems form honest recessionary fears or the knowledge that they can plausibly write-off their thrift as a response to recessionary fears is less clear.

But with summer dying down, Patterson Belknap has decided it’s able to share some of the wealth with its associates. Perhaps more exciting, in a nod to the mostly bygone era where associates were treated as professional colleagues rather than revenue vectors, the bonus will be offered without any hourly requirement and every associate will get the full amount for their class year (with provisions for newcomer pro-rating and those on part-time schedules).

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Here’s what the good folks of Patterson are looking at:

Class of 2019 $7500
Class of 2018 $7500
Class of 2017 $7500
Class of 2016 $10000
Class of 2015 $10000
Class of 2014 $12500
Class of 2013 $15000
Class of 2012 $30000
Class of 2011+ $40000

The firm’s memo notes that they aren’t in a position to make summer bonuses are annual tradition, but that they respect that exceptional financial performance — like the firm’s turned in over the first half of 2019 — calls for some remunerative celebration.

Congratulations to everyone at the firm. Hopefully some more firms will join the party.
